title: Aegiphila sellowiana
text:
Aegiphila sellowiana is a species of <a href="tree">tree</a> or <a href="shrub">shrub</a> in the family <a href="Lamiaceae">Lamiaceae</a>. It is native to <a href="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>, and <a href="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>. Its common names include tamanqueira.
In tree form it can grow seven meters tall. It produces oppositely arranged leaves up to 28 centimeters long and abundant <a href="drupe">drupe</a>s. The seeds are <a href="seed%20dispersal">dispersed</a> by birds that eat the fruits.
It often grows in <a href="riparian%20zone">riparian zone</a>s, where it tolerates <a href="flood">flood</a>ing. It is a <a href="pioneer%20species">pioneer species</a> sometimes used in <a href="revegetation">revegetation</a> efforts in riparian habitat in Brazil.
The soft wood has been used to make <a href="furniture">furniture</a> and shoes. It has been used in <a href="Brazilian%20traditional%20medicine">Brazilian traditional medicine</a> as an <a href="antivenom">antivenom</a> and <a href="anti-inflammatory">anti-inflammatory</a>.
This species is cited in "<a href="Flora%20Brasiliensis">Flora Brasiliensis</a>" by <a href="Carl%20Friedrich%20Philipp%20von%20Martius">Carl Friedrich Philipp von Martius</a>.
